reasoning: First, Apple squarely falls within my circle of competence: it’s a consumer products business with a powerful ecosystem and loyal customers—exactly the kind of company I understand. On its moat, the brand and switching costs are real, but the metrics are mixed. Operating margins above 43% show pricing power, yet a ROE of just 10.5% and ROIC under 7%—with only 1 out of 10 periods above 15% ROE—suggest the business isn’t deploying capital as efficiently as I’d like. Management has delivered in the past with share buybacks and innovation, but recent stock issuance and minimal dividends raise mild concerns about shareholder focus. The balance sheet, at a debt-to-equity of 0.54, isn’t a crisis, but inconsistent earnings growth (0 score) and lack of current ratio data leave gaps. Critically, my three-stage DCF pegs intrinsic value around $100,300 per share—or about $85,260 on a conservative basis—yet today’s price implies a negative 71% margin of safety. I’d rather own a wonderful business at a fair price than overpay for a good one. Long term, I admire Apple’s staying power, but at these levels I see limited upside and meaningful risk of capital loss. In comparison to other opportunities in my portfolio—like Coca-Cola, See’s Candies or our insurance operations—I’d deploy new capital elsewhere. Hence, bearish with about 80% confidence.
